g.text: 28. Ragone, F., Lucarini, V. & Lunkeit, F. A new framework for climate sensitivity and prediction: a modelling perspective.
29. Lucarini, V., Ragone, F. & Lunkeit, F. Predicting climate change using response theory: global averages and spatial patterns.
30. Newhouse, S. & Pignataro, T. On the estimation of topological entropy.
31. Ott, E. Chaos in dynamical systems.
32. Thiffeault, J.-L. Braids of entangled particle trajectories.
33. Budišić, M. & Thiffeault, J.-L. Finite-time braiding exponents.
34. Haszpra, T. & Tél, T. Topological entropy: a Lagrangian measure of the state of the free atmosphere.
35. Lin, J.-T. Relative dispersion in the enstrophy-cascading inertial range of homogeneous two-dimensional turbulence.
. Historical (1850–2000) gridded anthropogenic and biomass burning emissions of reactive gases and aerosols:
. The representative concentration pathways: an overview.
The author thanks the useful discussions with and suggestions of G. Drótos, T. Tél and M. Vincze. This paper was
supported by the János Bolyai Research Scholarship of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences and by the National
Research, Development and Innovation Office–NKFIH under grant PD-121305, PD-124272, FK-124256,
Both authors contributed to editing the manuscript and interpreting the results. M.H. carried out the climate
simulations in PlaSim and downloaded the CESM meteorological data. T.H. carried out the spreading simulations
with RePLaT and did the data processing.
The authors declare no competing interests.
